This is a really good read on general strategies <http://blog.venmo.com/hf2t3h4x98p5e13z82pl8j66ngcmry/performance-tuning-on-android>

attachments.title: Performance Tuning On Android
attachments.text: Earlier this summer, we released a major update to our Android app. It shipped with a revamped UI, a new robust networking layer, and plenty of awesome. Our users loved the new experience and responded with a lot of positive feedback. It was a great release, but we were a little unhappy with how smooth the UI was. Scrolling on the feed seemed choppy, especially when scrolling quickly.  So let’s talk about UI performance.
attachments.fallback: The Venmo Blog: Performance Tuning On Android

you can copy/paste them somewhere before you dismiss the dialog. or there's probably some option to keep your log from disappearing
or use logcat in command line (or pidcat)

or attach a debugger in Android Studio and have it pause on exceptions
if you use the command `adb logcat` from the terminal you can see all the logs - more history than Android Studio shows. I think its the same as turning off all the filters etc

text:
is there a good way to animate showing / hiding partial content of a viewgroup?
For example, I have a relativelayout whose contents are 400dp, and I only want to show the top 200dp of it.
But when I click a button, I want the relativelayout to "expand" and reveal the full contents
For TextView there's a library called ExpandableTextView
<https://github.com/Manabu-GT/ExpandableTextView>

attachments.title: Manabu-GT/ExpandableTextView
attachments.text: ExpandableTextView - Android's TextView that can expand/collapse like the Google Play's app description
